docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Reading ''Treated for Illness, Then Lost in Labyrinth of Bills,'' I recognized what my parents have gone through in recent years. In contrast, I've discovered the wonders of universal health care since moving from the United States to Canada.

headline.main: Health Bills: It's a Jungle Out There

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Reading ''Treated for Illness, Then Lost in Labyrinth of Bills,'' I recognized what my parents have gone through in recent years. In contrast, I've discovered the wonders of universal health care since moving from the United States...

docs.lead_paragraph: I have an employee with no health insurance -- he opted out of our company plan -- with a wife and children who rely on his income. He has been loyal and productive. I have no bad things to say about him. Recently he was diagnosed with cancer and will not be able to perform his job. Should I continue to pay his salary even after he stops working? How should employers handle such situations? Eric Markowitz, Brooklyn

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 10-16-05: THE ETHICIST

docs.snippet: "I have an employee with no health insurance - he opted out of our company plan - with a wife and children who rely on his income. ..."

docs.lead_paragraph: In Maspeth, a Queens neighborhood five miles east of and what seems like a time zone apart from Manhattan, women of a certain age still walk on the main shopping street, Grand Avenue, wearing gingham house dresses. There are benches on the sidewalks. People sit on them. If you happened to be in one of the local drugstores on a recent afternoon, you would have heard a man in a sleeveless shirt ask the pharmacist for advice about his sore arm.

headline.main: THE VOTERS: Maspeth, Queens; In Enclave, Biggest Vote Is in Favor Of Status Quo

docs.snippet: Maspeth, Queens, is a place so used to fighting its own battles that the Nov. 8 mayoral election sometimes seems irrelevant.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Eddy Curry takes the court for the first time this weekend wearing a Knicks uniform, basketball fans and executives will be holding their breath wondering whether his heart will skip a beat again. The Knicks hope Curry is the long-awaited solution at center -- nothing more, and nothing less.

headline.main: The Knicks Have a Test Case in Medical Ethics

docs.snippet: Eddy Curry is a 6-foot-11, 285-pound test case in ethics, pushing legal, medical and athletic boundaries with the questions that his irregular heartbeat in March prompted.

docs.lead_paragraph: Apple Selects a Worldwide Sales Executive To Become Its Chief Operating Officer Apple Computer has named Tim Cook, the company's executive vice president for worldwide sales and operations, as chief operating officer. Mr. Cook, left, who took over day-to-day operations during chief executive Steven P. Jobs' recovery from cancer surgery last year, will essentially become the No.2 person at Apple. ''Tim has been doing this job for over two years now, and it's high time we officially recognized it with this promotion,'' Mr. Jobs said in a statement. Mr. Cook, 44, will continue to overseeing worldwide operations and leading the Macintosh division, and will work with Mr. Jobs and the executive team to lead Apple's overall business, Apple said. The company also said Jon Rubinstein, head of the iPod unit, will retire March 31 and be succeeded by Tony Fadell, vice president for iPod engineering. (AP) Pension Agency Objects to Airline's Reorganization Plan The government agency that insures corporate pensions has objected to United Airlines' reorganization plan, saying in court documents that the carrier has changed a deal covering the termination of its pensions. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said in a filing that the airline's disclosure statement, which details its financial model, is ''unconfirmable.'' United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, must get bankruptcy court approval of the statement before asking creditors to vote on restructuring. The agency complained that the plan was inconsistent with a settlement the parties reached last spring for the airline to turn its pensions over to the government. (Reuters) Medical Device Maker Posts a Quarterly Loss Boston Scientific said yesterday that it had lost ground to its only medical device rival in the lucrative market for drug-coated heart stents, reporting a $269 million third-quarter loss and slowing sales of a stent that provided big profits last year. The performance, hurt by a $598 million expense for a legal settlement, fell short of company's projection and Wall Street's expectations. Boston Scientific executives said in a conference call with analysts that its Taxus stent has lost market share to the Cypher stent made by Johnson & Johnson's Cordis Corporation. The company, based in Natick, Mass., said it lost 33 cents a share and the results compared with a profit of $258 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 2 percent, to $1.51 billion. (AP) Bank of America's Purchase of MBNA Advances Delaware's banking commissioner yesterday approved the proposed $35 billion acquisition of MBNA by the Bank of America Corporation, moving the buyout of the world's largest independent credit card issuer one step closer to completion. The approval of the Delaware banking commissioner, Robert Glen, was required because MBNA is based in Wilmington, Del. Bank of America is based in Charlotte, N.C. (AP) Justice Department Approves Software Merger Adobe Systems said late Thursday that the Justice Department had approved its $3.4 billion acquisition of Macromedia. Adobe and Macromedia, two of the largest providers of graphic design software, must wait for several European jurisdictions to approve the deal before it can close. Adobe's Illustrator and Macromedia's Freehand are two of the leading products for vector graphics illustration, a term for drawings that are stored as collections of points and objects instead of pixels. A combined company would also own a substantial part of the market for Web site-building tools. (AP) Profit Rises 21 Percent at Insurer UnitedHealth The UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation's largest health insurance companies, reported a 21 percent increase in third-quarter profit on membership gains and lower-than-expected medical costs. The company forecast profit growth would continue through 2006 at an annual rate of at least 15 percent. UnitedHealth predicted a Medicare prescription drug benefit would add 2 million to 3 million members to its rolls next year, potentially increasing 2006 earnings by 5 cents a share. UnitedHealth said it expected to complete its acquisition of PacifiCare Health by year-end or early in 2006. UnitedHealth said its third-quarter profit rose to $842 million, or 64 cents a share, from $698 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 15 percent, to $11.3 billion. (Reuters) Bush Seeks End to Lumber Trade Dispute With Canada President Bush told the Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin yesterday that it was time to find a solution to a long-running trade fight between the two countries over softwood lumber. A White House spokesman, Scott McClellan, said Mr. Bush and Mr. Martin spoke by telephone for about 20 minutes, and trade was a major part of their discussion. Mr. Martin criticized the United States government last week for its position on trade in lumber, saying Washington was ignoring a North American Free Trade Agreement ruling against United States duties on Canadian softwood lumber. (Reuters) Developer's Bid for British Grocer Is Accepted A billionaire property developer, Robert Tchenguiz, and two partners won the right to buy Somerfield, a British grocer, for £1.08 billion ($1.9 billion) to gain control of its real estate. The bid, 197 pence for each share in Somerfield, was accepted, Anthony Cardew, a spokesman for Somerfield, said yesterday. The investor group includes Tchenguiz, Apax Partners Worldwide and Barclays Capital. Mr. Tchenguiz will get control of 1,300 Somerfield and Kwik Save stores. Somerfield is based in Bristol, England. (Bloomberg News)

docs.lead_paragraph: The 48 million Americans who receive Social Security will get a 4.1 percent increase in their monthly checks next year, the largest increase in 15 years, the Bush administration said Friday. The average benefit for a retired worker will rise by $39, to $1,002 a month.

headline.main: Benefit Rising By 4 Percent, But Medicare Takes a Share

docs.snippet: The 48 million Americans who receive Social Security will get a 4.1 percent increase in their monthly checks next year, the largest increase in 15 years.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE rise in specialty food sales is nothing new. Salsa has been the No.1 condiment in the United States for some time. What is different is the approach companies are taking with these products, Business 2.0 reports this month. ''Instead of targeting mass markets, these specialty brands are aimed at immigrant populations with the hope that demand will migrate to the general public,'' Elizabeth Esfahani writes.
docs.snippet: The rise in specialty food sales is nothing new. What is different is the approach companies are taking with these products, Business 2.0 reports this month.

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Electric Company, making good on its promise last week of stellar third-quarter earnings, said yesterday that its profit for the quarter was up 15 percent on revenue that rose 9 percent, and that the fourth quarter and next year were shaping up to be highly profitable. ''You are going to see some massively good numbers in the future,'' Jeffrey R. Immelt, G.E.'s chairman, told analysts in a conference call.

headline.main: G.E. Reports Big Gains In Earnings And Revenue

docs.snippet: The General Electric Company said Friday that its profit for the quarter was up 15 percent on revenue that rose 9 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: General Motors and the United Auto Workers union are near an agreement that would help the automaker cut some of its nearly $6 billion a year in health care costs, the union said Friday. The union and G.M. are expected to continue negotiations over the weekend, but neither side would speculate about the timing of a deal, which would end six months of talks over what the automaker has said is its most pressing financial problem.
docs.snippet: General Motors and the United Auto Workers union are near an agreement that would help the automaker cut some of its nearly $6 billion a year in health care costs, the union said Friday.      The union and G.M. are expected to continue negotiations...

docs.lead_paragraph: Fighting obvious emotion as she stood with her family and addressed several hundred cheering supporters, Gov. M. Jodi Rell formally announced her candidacy for governor on Friday, saying she would seek ''my own term'' in the office she inherited 15 months ago from a predecessor who resigned and is now in prison. ''You know what I like the most, what I take the most pride in as your governor?'' she said near the end of her nine-minute speech, delivered in the atrium of the 126-year-old Capitol building after rain forced the event inside. ''It's that the people of Connecticut have come to believe in me -- and I am honored and humbled by their belief.''

headline.main: Rell Announces She Will Seek Her Own Term

docs.snippet: Gov. M. Jodi Rell of Connecticut formally announced her candidacy for the office she inherited from John G. Rowland.
